channel.title: OnOptions
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from OnOptions, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: I Prefer Working In-Person, But My Employees Want to Be Remote
item.description: … and two other tricky workplace dilemmas.

item.title: Lindsay Hubbard Has Made an Empire Out of Being Herself
item.description: The Summer House veteran on charging premium rates for brand deals, and helping her castmates (and dates!) navigate entrepreneurship.

item.title: Moltbook, the viral social media site for AI bots, contains a ‘lethal trifecta’ for how the agent internet could fail, security researchers say
item.description: “If toy agents on a Reddit clone can create this much chaos, what happens when agentic systems manage enterprise infrastructure or financial transacti...

item.title: AI in healthcare is entering a new era of accountability

item.title: Why President Trump’s latest crypto scandal could spell disaster for the blockchain industry
item.description: A bombshell report revealed that an Abu Dhabi royal bought a 49% stake in Trump’s flagship crypto project.

item.title: Culture isn’t what you say, it’s what you do
item.description: I’ve read a lot of books on building a culture at work. A lot of the advice is well intentioned but to me overly complex. A 20-step framework is a lot...

item.title: This super simple tripod is designed for the modern age
item.description: The humble tripod is an unheralded but essential part of any film or photo shoot. It’s the key to making shots level and pans smooth, and as a piece o...

item.title: What happened at Davos was a warning to CEOs: their companies are designed for a world that no longer exists
item.description: When allies hedge, CEOs must decide.

item.title: AI is changing the CEO’s role—and could lead to a changing of the guard
item.description: Even seasoned CEOs must show they can match the speed of technological change—and generate tangible returns from investments in it.

item.title: 4 Surprising Signs You’re Smarter Than You Think, Backed by Science
item.description: For example, frequently changing your mind doesn’t mean you’re wishy-washy; it means you’re smart enough to constantly reevaluate.

item.title: Did Target’s CEO miss the mark by ignoring Minnesota?
item.description: Also: All the news and watercooler chat from Fortune.

item.title: Psychology Says Civil Conversations Can Change Minds More Than Your Think
item.description: New research suggests we’re way too nervous about discussing politics. The right tone goes a long way.
